'''Hurricane Madeline''' was a Category 4 hurricane that made landfall in [[Mexico]] in October 1976. Madeline formed on September 29, not far from [[Central America]]. The next day, the circulation dissipated, and as a result weakened to a [[low-pressure area|remnant low]]. Four days later, on October 3, the low regenerated into a tropical depression. The system remained weak for three days as it drifted west-northwest. When it began to recurve towards Mexico on October 6, the cyclone rapidly intensified, eventually making landfall at peak intensity as a Category 4. Shortly after landfall, the cyclone rapidly dissipated.
Prior to the arrival of Madeline, 15,000 people evacuated form the coast, which had already been impacted by [[Hurricane Liza (1976)|Hurricane Liza]]. Heavy damage was reported, along with seven fatalities. Two dams were flooded; extensive crop damage was reported.
==Meteorological history== {{storm path|Madeline 1976 track.png|alt text=Storm path of Hurricane Madeline}} Early on September 27, 1976, the [[Eastern Pacific Hurricane Center]] (EPHC) reported that a tropical disturbance had formed about 770 km (480 mi) to the southwest of [[San Jose, Costa Rica]].<ref name="Seasonal summary">{{cite journal|author=Emil B Gunther|volume=105|date=1977-04-01|title=Eastern Pacific Tropical Cyclones of 1976|journal=Monthly Weather Review|publisher=American Meteorological Society|pages=508â522|url=http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/pdf/10.1175/1520-0493%281977%29105%3C0508%3AEPTCO%3E2.0.CO%3B2|accessdate=2010-04-25|doi=10.1175/1520-0493(1977)105<0508:EPTCO>2.0.CO;2|issn=1520-0493|year=1977|issue=4|bibcode = 1977MWRv..105..508G }}</ref> During the next two days the disturbance slowly developed while moving northwest. By the morning of September 29, the disturbance was upgraded to a 40 mph (65 km/h) tropical storm and based on ship reports and [[satellite imagery]]. Due to the fact that it attained tropical storm status, it was named Madeline. At this time, the cyclone had developed a center of circulation.<ref name="Seasonal summary"/>{{EPAC hurricane best track}} Its intensification was short-lived and Madeline remained at [[tropical cyclone|tropical storm]] strength for just 12 hours before it was downgraded into a [[tropical cyclone|tropical depression]].<ref name="Seasonal summary"/><ref name="EPAC HURDAT">{{cite web|title=Eastern Pacific hurricane best track analysis 1949-2009|publisher=[[National Hurricane Center]]|date=2010-03-01|accessdate=2010-04-24|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/tracks1949to2009_epa.txt}}</ref> Madeline remained at tropical depression strength until September 20. At that time, the EPHC reported that the circulation center was no longer visible and downgraded the system to a remnant low, while located 575 mi (925 km) to the southeast of [[Acapulco, Mexico]].<ref name="Seasonal summary"/>
Over the following days, the low moved towards the west and started to regenerate with a circulation center becoming visible early on October 3. Based on this, the EPHC re-upgraded Madeline to a tropical depression.<ref name="Seasonal summary"/><ref name="EPAC HURDAT"/> Continuing to intensify, Madeline was soon upgraded to a tropical storm for the second time.<ref name="EPAC HURDAT"/> During the next day or two, Madeline remained near stationary before turning towards the northeast on October 5.<ref name="Seasonal summary" /> As the cyclone moved over an area of warm seas surface temperatures, the storm started to intensify. During the next day, Madeline slowly developed an [[eye (cyclone)|eye]] before intensifying into a hurricane. In addition, a [[Hurricane Hunter]] aircraft reported winds 75 mph (120 km/h) winds and a pressure of 984 millibars<ref name="Seasonal summary"/><ref name="EPAC HURDAT" />
During October 7, with warm water helping to fuel its intensification, Madeline quickly intensified into a Category 2 hurricane, and was upgraded to a major hurricane (Category 3 or higher on the [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale]]) early on October 8. Based on hurricane hunter reports, Madeline reached its peak [[maximum sustained winds|sustained winds]] of 145 mph (230 km/h) and a peak pressure of 940 [[bar (unit)|millibars]] early on the 8 . Upon reaching peak intensity, it peak gust from the powerful hurricane was 165 mph (270 km/h). This made Madeline a moderate Category 4 hurricane. Later that morning Madeline made landfall to the northwest of [[Zihuatanejo]] as a powerful Category 4 hurricane, before it rapidly dissipated over land.<ref name="Seasonal summary"/><ref name="EPAC HURDAT"/>
==Preparations and impact== [[File:Madeline1976filledrainblk.gif|thumb|right|Rainfall from Hurricane Madeline]] Mexican army headquarters put in effect an emergency plan three days prior to the arrival of the hurricane.<ref name="HM VI" /> An estimated 15,000 people evacuated from threatened areas in the path of Madeline.<ref name="HM IX">{{cite web|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=W1AxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=86EFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6170,2843183&dq=hurricane+madeline&hl=en|title=Measures keep toll low|date=1976-08-10|work=The Montreal Gazette|page=66|accessdate=2010-04-03}}</ref> According to one report, evacuations prior to Madeline were considered a success.<ref name="HM VI"/> [[Tropical cyclone warnings and watches|Hurricane warnings]] and [[Flood alert|flood warnings]] were issued along the coastlines of [[MichoacÃ¡n]] and [[Guerrero]]. In addition, [[Tropical cyclone warnings and watches|tropical storm warnings]] were issued for nine states in Mexico. This warning area extended as far inland as the area west of the [[Gulf of Mexico]].<ref name="HMIII">{{cite web|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=M5YtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EqEFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5998,3967903&dq=hurricane+madeline&hl=en|title=Madline Padlin' to land|date=1976-10-07|work=Reading Eagle|accessdate=2010-04-03}}</ref>
Hurricane Madeline produced heavy rains over [[Mexico]], peaking at {{convert|16.57|in|mm|abbr=on}}, rainfall fell at El Povenir/San Marcos. According to Comision Nacional del Agua, a parent agency of the [[Servicio MeteorolÃ³gico Nacional]], rainfall fell at 2,069 sites.<ref name=HPC>{{cite web|url=http://www.hpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/madeline1976.html|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|title=Hurricane Madeline â October 6â9, 1976|accessdate=2007-07-19}}</ref> Damage from the hurricane was considered to be severe.<ref name="Seasonal summary"/> In [[Chilpancingo]], Guerrero, two people drowned from the hurricane. In addition, five other deaths were reported.<ref name="HM IX" /> The cyclone also flooded two major hydro-electrical dams and power outages were reported.<ref name=HMIII/> While no serious damage was reported in [[Zihuatanejo]],<ref name="HM VI"/> many boats were damaged.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NJYtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EqEFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4214,4965121&dq=hurricane+madeline&hl=en|title=High and Dry Motorboat|date=1976-10-08|work=Reading Eagle|pages=24|accessdate=2010-04-03}}</ref> In addition, the storm caused extensive crop damage.<ref name="HM VI">{{cite web|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7O4vAAAAIBAJ&sjid=wvoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5221,2297187&dq=hurricane+madeline&hl=en|title=Hurricane Madeline moves across Mexico|date=1976-10-08|work=Lake land Ledger|pages=7|accessdate=2010-04-03}}</ref> Losses from Madeline, combined with previous hurricanes [[Hurricane Liza (1976)|Liza]] and [[Hurricane Kathleen (1976)|Kathleen]], were estimated at $200 million (1976 USD).<ref name="HM VIII">{{cite web|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=jnwoAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QsoEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1375,2997506&dq=hurricane+madeline&hl=en|title=Hurricane Madeline|work=Dayton Beach Morning Journal|accessdate=2010-04-03}}</ref> It was the second storm to strike Mexico within a week; Hurricane Liza was the first.<ref name="HMX">{{cite news|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/658545372.html?dids=658545372:658545372&FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:AI&type=historic&date=Oct+10%2C+1976&author=&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=Photo+Standalone+1+--+No+Title&pqatl=google|title=Hurricane Madeline|publisher=LA Times|pages=1|accessdate=2010-04-03 | first=AP | last=Wirephoto | date=1976-10-10}}</ref> When Madeline was over the ocean, it impacted several ships, but no major damage from these ships was reported.<ref name="Seasonal summary"/>
